text: As I noted in a previous post, we’re not done with Enshrouded yet.  We still meet up once a week to go do something as a group.  But the current state of early access has us hemmed in on larger objectives.  Basically, for a lot of the game we have now been there and have, in fact, done that. Welcome to Enshrouded I spent some extra time on my own in the game over the last week chasing the final achievements I had left in the game. My final six achievements The “spark” achievements were deceptively difficult because, as I eventually found out, when you visit the obelisks… which are their own achievement… they put all the flame shrines on your map.  However, unlike shroud roots, there is no additional mark to let you know you’ve been there. So if you’ve explored most of the map, you can have a whole host of shrines on it but not be quite sure if you have ever visited them or not.  Eventually I had to follow the suggestion I read and put markers on the map after I visited each one… again… until I ran down the eight or so I had never been to. The pieces of the north turned out to just be an area search once I read that all of the pieces were in containers… chests or coffins… in Pikemead’s Reach.  I had already grabbed the one you need to defeat the boss to get, so it was an evening of exploring the place thoroughly to find the remaining four pieces. And with that done, I had all the achievements. Enshrouded Achievements Complete It is somewhat amusing that, on my profile, my rarest achievement listing is about half occupied by Enshrouded achievements. My rare achievement showcase As you can see, I now have exactly ONE game on Steam where I have managed to collect ALL the achievements.  And that will no doubt be taken away when more content drops and achievements are added.  But I will savor the win for the moment. I have also chased down all the shroud roots in the current expanse of the game, which means I have what I believe to be the maximum number of skill points available in the game, which is 149. My skill point total Did I spend them wisely?  Maybe not.  But the respec process is pretty easy.  Since the last big patch you can just un-select specific skills to get your points back when you visit your flame shrine.  Much better than the bad old days of Diablo II when once you spent a talent point, you were stuck with it forever. (That was bad enough that Blizz eventually gave us a very limited respec.) This past weekend we hunted down the last cyclops cave and killed its resident. Another cyclops down That gave us all the pieces… we have legs, arms, torso and head, we were just missing the pelvis… to assemble the cyclops statue/monument… or so we thought. It turns out that the final assembly requires the ectoplasm building block, which is something we missed in the Nomad Highlands Hollow Halls.  So we’re set for a return trip there. Potshot and Ula also have a couple more shroud roots to track down, something we can do as a group easily enough.  We grabbed a few more this past weekend, so there should not be too many left. This one is surrounded by shroud lava You can barely see the shroud root in that image above, shrouded in mist, basically straight up from the right horn on my helm.  That was a comedy of errors as gliding down there was easy, but managing the precision landing required not to overshoot or bounce off something and end up in the shroud lava… which zeroes out your shroud timer in about three seconds at which point you die and you corpse is sitting in the lava where it is difficult, if not impossible, to revive. So there were issues, and eventually a landing zone was carved out of some nearby landscape, with a crash barrier at the end, so we could descend safely and chop down the root. Mission accomplished, eventually. Again, not done yet.  We still have things to do.  But we’re also looking forward to the next big content update, which according to the roadmap to release is a water biome.  Oh dear.
html:
As I noted in a previous post, we’re not done with Enshrouded yet.  We still meet up once a week to go do something as a group.  But the current state of early access has us hemmed in on larger objectives.  Basically, for a lot of the game we have now been there and have, in fact, done that.

Welcome to Enshrouded

I spent some extra time on my own in the game over the last week chasing the final achievements I had left in the game.

My final six achievements

The “spark” achievements were deceptively difficult because, as I eventually found out, when you visit the obelisks… which are their own achievement… they put all the flame shrines on your map.  However, unlike shroud roots, there is no additional mark to let you know you’ve been there.

So if you’ve explored most of the map, you can have a whole host of shrines on it but not be quite sure if you have ever visited them or not.  Eventually I had to follow the suggestion I read and put markers on the map after I visited each one… again… until I ran down the eight or so I had never been to.

The pieces of the north turned out to just be an area search once I read that all of the pieces were in containers… chests or coffins… in Pikemead’s Reach.  I had already grabbed the one you need to defeat the boss to get, so it was an evening of exploring the place thoroughly to find the remaining four pieces.

And with that done, I had all the achievements.

Enshrouded Achievements Complete

It is somewhat amusing that, on my profile, my rarest achievement listing is about half occupied by Enshrouded achievements.

My rare achievement showcase

As you can see, I now have exactly ONE game on Steam where I have managed to collect ALL the achievements.  And that will no doubt be taken away when more content drops and achievements are added.  But I will savor the win for the moment.

I have also chased down all the shroud roots in the current expanse of the game, which means I have what I believe to be the maximum number of skill points available in the game, which is 149.

My skill point total

Did I spend them wisely?  Maybe not.  But the respec process is pretty easy.  Since the last big patch you can just un-select specific skills to get your points back when you visit your flame shrine.  Much better than the bad old days of Diablo II when once you spent a talent point, you were stuck with it forever. (That was bad enough that Blizz eventually gave us a very limited respec.)

This past weekend we hunted down the last cyclops cave and killed its resident.

Another cyclops down

That gave us all the pieces… we have legs, arms, torso and head, we were just missing the pelvis… to assemble the cyclops statue/monument… or so we thought.

It turns out that the final assembly requires the ectoplasm building block, which is something we missed in the Nomad Highlands Hollow Halls.  So we’re set for a return trip there.

Potshot and Ula also have a couple more shroud roots to track down, something we can do as a group easily enough.  We grabbed a few more this past weekend, so there should not be too many left.

This one is surrounded by shroud lava

You can barely see the shroud root in that image above, shrouded in mist, basically straight up from the right horn on my helm.  That was a comedy of errors as gliding down there was easy, but managing the precision landing required not to overshoot or bounce off something and end up in the shroud lava… which zeroes out your shroud timer in about three seconds at which point you die and you corpse is sitting in the lava where it is difficult, if not impossible, to revive.

So there were issues, and eventually a landing zone was carved out of some nearby landscape, with a crash barrier at the end, so we could descend safely and chop down the root.

Mission accomplished, eventually.

Again, not done yet.  We still have things to do.  But we’re also looking forward to the next big content update, which according to the roadmap to release is a water biome.  Oh dear.
